results.adx_keywords: Restaurants;Workplace Hazards and Violations;Shutdowns (Institutional);Internships;Chefs;internal-sub-only;audio-positive-escape;Redzepi, Rene;Noma (Copenhagen, Restaurant);Copenhagen (Denmark)
results.title: Noma, Rated the World’s Best Restaurant, Is Closing Its Doors
results.abstract: The Copenhagen chef René Redzepi says fine dining at the highest level, with its grueling hours and intense workplace culture, has hit a breaking point: “It’s unsustainable.”

media.copyright: Erik Refner for The New York Times

results.title: Prince Harry’s Bridge-Burner of a Memoir Signals a Bigger Royal Rift
results.abstract: The self-exiled royal has given the world a warts-and-all look at his family — with an emphasis on the warts.
per_facet: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom

media.caption: Prince Harry, Meghan, King Charles and his wife, Camilla, at the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II in September.

results.byline: By Ken Belson and Jenny Vrentas
results.title: Who Told Players to Warm Up After Damar Hamlin Collapsed?
results.abstract: ESPN told viewers that players were given five minutes to warm up after Hamlin was taken off the field. The N.F.L. denied that. On Sunday, Commissioner Roger Goodell addressed the question.

media.caption: After Damar Hamlin was injured in a game on Jan. 2, Joe Burrow of the Cincinnati Bengals, center, warmed up briefly before the game was suspended.
media.copyright: Sam Greene/USA Today Sports, via Reuters

results.byline: By Ed Shanahan and Joshua Needelman
results.title: Brooklyn Judge Accused of Making Racist and Homophobic Remarks Resigns
results.abstract: Misconduct claims against Judge Harriet Thompson of Brooklyn Surrogate’s Court were scheduled to be considered at a hearing next week.

media.caption: Judge Harriet L. Thompson at her induction ceremony in Brooklyn in 2019. She was accused of making racist and homophobic remarks.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Fatalities);Snow and Snowstorms;Avalanches;Colorado;Winter Park (Colo)
results.title: Two Snowmobilers Killed in Colorado Avalanche
results.abstract: Dog and helicopter rescue teams helped with the weekend searches near Winter Park, Colo. The danger of avalanche conditions in the area was “considerable” on Saturday.

media.caption: Corona Pass, an area also known as Rollins Pass, where a second person was found on Sunday morning, after an avalanche in Winter Park, Colo.

results.adx_keywords: Colleges and Universities;Academic Freedom;Muslim Americans;Discrimination;Muslims and Islam;Freedom of Speech and Expression;Art;internal-sub-only;Lopez Prater, Erika;Gruber, Christiane;Hamline University;St Paul (Minn)
results.title: A Lecturer Showed a Painting of the Prophet Muhammad. She Lost Her Job.
results.abstract: After an outcry over the art history class by Muslim students, Hamline University officials said the incident was Islamophobic. But many scholars say the work is a masterpiece.

media.caption: Officials at Hamline, in St. Paul, Minn., had tried to douse what they feared would become a runaway fire. Instead they ended embroiled in a national controversy.
media.copyright: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: United States Politics and Government;Tax Evasion;Inflation Reduction Act of 2022;Congressional Budget Office;House Committee on Ways and Means;House of Representatives;Republican Party;Internal Revenue Service
results.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Alan Rappeport
results.title: House Republicans Vote to Rescind I.R.S. Funding
results.abstract: The measure, one of the new majority’s first legislative moves, would cut billions in funding that Democrats passed to help crack down on tax cheats. It does not have enough votes to pass the Senate.
org_facet: House Committee on Ways and Means

media.caption: Representative Jason Smith, who clinched the chairmanship of the Ways and Means Committee on Monday, warned that his committee would increase scrutiny of the I.R.S.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Holocaust and the Nazi Era;World War II (1939-45);Forgery;Jews and Judaism;Kaminsky, Adolfo (1925-2023)
results.title: Adolfo Kaminsky Dies at 97; His Forgeries Saved Thousands of Jews
results.abstract: His talent for creating realistic documents helped children, their parents and others escape deportation to concentration camps, and in many cases to flee Nazi-occupied territory.

media.caption: Adolfo Kaminsky at his home in Paris in 2012. After his wartime exploits in forgery, he became a photographer and photography teacher.

results.adx_keywords: Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Drones (Pilotless Planes);vis-photo;Prigozhin, Yevgeny V;Wagner Group;Bakhmut (Ukraine);Donbas (Ukraine)
results.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung
results.title: Without Hesitation, Ukraine Goes Toe to Toe With Russia in Bakhmut
results.abstract: Earlier in the war, Ukraine’s leadership was more equivocal about pitched battles with high casualties. There’s no second-guessing this time. Some analysts say it makes sense strategically.

media.caption: Ukrainian military analysts on Friday near Bakhmut, in the country’s east, reviewing videos obtained by drone operators.
media.copyright: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Royal Families;Books and Literature;Harry, Duke of Sussex;Markle, Meghan;William, Duke of Cambridge
results.title: Has Prince Harry’s Confessional Tour Run Its Course?
results.abstract: Even in the United States, which has a high tolerance for redemptive stories about overcoming trauma and family dysfunction, the tide seems to be turning.

media.caption: Prince Harry’s memoir, “Spare,” went on sale early in Spain, where it was snapped up and translated by alert members of the British media.
media.copyright: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.byline: By Peter Baker, Charlie Savage, Glenn Thrush and Adam Goldman
results.title: Biden Lawyers Found Classified Material at His Former Office
results.abstract: The White House said it was cooperating as the Justice Department scrutinizes the matter.

media.caption: “A small number” of classified documents were discovered in President Biden’s former office at a Washington think tank, the White House said.
media.copyright: Pete Marovich for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Restaurants;Chefs;Redzepi, Rene;Noma (Copenhagen, Restaurant)
results.title: Noma Spawned a World of Imitators, but the Restaurant Remains an Original
results.abstract: As the renowned Copenhagen destination prepares to end its regular service, Pete Wells examines its complicated legacy.

media.caption: Perhaps no other restaurant has come up with as many ideas that were shoplifted by as many other chefs in as many other cities.
media.copyright: Ditte Isager for The New York Times

results.title: Nurses Go on Strike at 2 New York City Hospitals
results.abstract: More than 7,000 nurses at Mount Sinai Medical Center and Montefiore Medical Center are seeking better wages and working conditions.

results.title: Woman in GoFundMe Scam Gets 3 Years in New Jersey Prison
results.abstract: Prosecutors said Katelyn McClure and her boyfriend at the time spun a tale that helped them raise more than $400,000 for a homeless man. All three were eventually charged.

media.caption: Katelyn McClure at the Burlington County Courthouse with her lawyer, Jim Gerrow Jr., in Mount Holly, N.J., in 2019.

results.adx_keywords: Cats;Pets;Animal Behavior;Animal Cognition;Research;your-feed-science;Animal Cognition (Journal)
results.title: Your Cat Might Not Be Ignoring You When You Speak
results.abstract: Cats have a reputation for being aloof, but a new study has found that their relationships with their owners may be stronger than we thought.

media.caption: Cats are often seen as aloof. But in a new study, they were not ignoring their owners, but instead “their reactions were very subtle,” the lead author of the study said.

results.adx_keywords: Content Type: Service;Psychology and Psychologists;Research;Conversation;Empathy;Friendship;Emotions;Anxiety and Stress
results.title: The Best Way to Comfort Someone When They’re Sad
results.abstract: A limited yet growing body of research suggests that one of the most powerful ways to support someone is also the simplest: Start a conversation.

results.title: A Family Found a Hibernating Bear Under a Deck. They’re Letting It Stay.
results.abstract: The black bear was found nesting on a bed of leaves in a crawl space of their house in Plainville, Conn., last month. A TikTok video of the bear has been viewed more than 15 million times.

media.caption: Vinny Dashukewich of Plainville, Conn., and his sister Tyler have named the bear Marty Bearnard.

results.byline: By The New York Times Books Staff
results.title: 11 Takeaways From Prince Harry’s Memoir, ‘Spare’
results.abstract: The much-anticipated book offers few revelations, in the wake of leaks and high-profile interviews, but it tucks familiar incidents into a broader narrative.

media.caption: Prince Harry’s memoir shows two brothers often at odds, and details other family rifts.

results.title: Adam Rich, Child Star on ‘Eight Is Enough,’ Dies at 54
results.abstract: Mr. Rich played Nicholas Bradford, the youngest son who was known for his glossy pageboy haircut, in the hit television series “Eight Is Enough” in the 1970s and ’80s.

media.caption: Adam Rich played Nicholas Bradford, the youngest of eight children, in “Eight Is Enough,” a television series that aired on ABC for five seasons.

results.title: Why Does My Sleep Become Worse as I Age?
